title: Carathéodory's theorem (convex hull)
summary: Carathéodory's theorem is a theorem in convex geometry. It states that if a point x {\displaystyle x} lies in the convex hull C o n v ( P ) {\displaystyle \mathrm {Conv} (P)} of a set P ⊂ R d {\displaystyle P\subset \mathbb {R} ^{d}} , then x {\displaystyle x} can be written as the convex combination of at most d + 1 {\displaystyle d+1} points in P {\displaystyle P} . More sharply, x {\displaystyle x} can be written as the convex combination of at most d + 1 {\displaystyle d+1} extremal points in P {\displaystyle P} , as non-extremal points can be removed from P {\displaystyle P} without changing the membership of x {\displaystyle x} in the convex hull.
